Limb Length Tibia Length Adult Tibia Length Fore, Adhesive Discs Presence, Geothermal Wetlands Wetlands, Oases Wetlands, Arctic Biogeographical Region, Stage Adult, Dispersal Distance, Parents Transport, South America Distribution, Moutain Peaks Caves, Molge Tridactyla Terdigitata, Siren Anguina Pseude, Tropical Shrub, Intrinsic Factors, Pannonian Biogeographical Region
A database of life-history traits of European amphibians

In the current context of climate change and landscape fragmentation, efficient conservation strategies require the explicit consideration of life history traits. This is particularly true for amphibians, which are highly threatened worldwide, composed by more than 7400 species, which is constitute one of the most species-rich vertebrate groups. The collection of information on life history traits is difficult due to the ecology of species and remoteness of their habitats. It is therefore not surprising that our knowledge is limited, and missing information on certain life history traits are common for in this species group. We compiled data on amphibian life history traits from literature in an extensive database with morphological and behavioral traits, habitat preferences and movement abilities for 86 European amphibian species (50 Anuran and 36 Urodela species). When it were available, we reported data for males, females, juveniles and tadpoles. Our database may serve as an important starting point for further analyses regarding amphibian conservation.

Body mass in females Body mass in males, in grams. Adult body mass Body mass in juveniles Body mass in juveniles, in grams. No distinction between sexes was available. Difference in ornamentation (coloration) or in size (length of tail, size of head or body size) between sexes. In amphibians, females are generally bigger than males. This difference may be caused by natural selection of a large female size due to a fecundity advantage. This phenotypic difference in size is often explained by sexual selection. Absence of sexual dimorphism. Presence of sexual dimorphism. Body mass in males, females or both when sex specific data were not available. Body mass in adults, without distinction between males and females, in grams. This data was recorded when no sex specific data on body mass were available in the literature. A measurement of the longest dimension of a body, typically between two distinct ends of the body. In amphibians, the distance snout-to-vent length is usually measured. To take into account the tail length in Urodela, we also reported a total length for each species, in males, in females or both when sex-specific data were not available. Measurement between the snout and the vent in males (in millimeters). Measurement between the snout and the vent in females (in millimeters). Measurement between the snout and the vent in adults, when no sex specific data were available (in millimeters). In Anura, this measure was similar to the snout-to-vent length. In Urodela, this measurement takes into account the tail length. Total length in males Measure of the total body length in males, in millimeters. Total length in females Measure of the total body length in females, in millimeters. Proportion of the head length compared to the body length. 0: Head length is not lower than body length. 1: Head length is lower than body length. 0: Head length is not similar to body length. 1: Head length is similar to body length. 0: Head length is not longer than body length. 1: Head length is longer than body length. Measurements of limb (foot, tibia and hind limb) in males, in females, or both when data were not sex specific available. Measurement of the foot in millimeters. Foot length in males Measurement of the foot in males, in millimeters. Foot length in females Measurement of the foot in females, in millimeters. Hind limb length in males Measurement of the hind limb in males, in millimeters. Adult total length Head and body length proportion Limb length Foot length Adult foot length Hind limb length Adult hind limb length Tibia length Adult tibia length Fore and hind limb proportion Tibia length in males Measurement of the tibia in males, in millimeters. Tibia length in females Measurement of the tibia in females, in millimeters. Measurement of the foot in adults, when no sex specific data were available, in millimeters. Measurement of the hind limb, in millimeters. Measurement of the hind limb in females, in millimeters. Measurement of the hind limb in adults, when no sex specific data were available, in millimeters. Measurement of the tibia, in millimeters. Measurement of the tibia in adults, when no sex specific data were available, in millimeters. Proportion of the fore limb length compared to the hind limb length. 0: Fore limb length is not lower than hind limb length. 1: Fore limb length is lower than hind limb length. 0: Fore limb length is not similar to hind limb length. 1: Fore limb length is similar to hind limb length. 0: Fore limb length is not longer than hind limb length. 1: Fore limb length is longer than hind limb length. Fingers and webbing Presence of discs Presence of webbing Some amphibians have adhesive discs at the ends of the toes and fingers. Absence of adhesive discs Presence of adhesive discs on fingers and/or on toes. 0: Absence of webbing. 1: Presence of webbing on toes and/or fingers 0: Absence of webbing on toes only. 1: Presence of webbing on toes only. Presence of webbing on toes and fingers 0: Absence of webbing on toes and fingers. 1: Presence of webbing on toes and fingers. Reduction on fingers only 0: Individuals have less than 5 toes and 4 fingers. 1: Individuals have 5 toes and 4 fingers. Reduction on fingers and 0: Individuals have 5 toes and 4 fingers. toes 1: Individuals have less than 5 toes and 4 fingers. Dorsoseparation Absence of metatarsal tubercle. Presence of metatarsal tubercle. 0: Dorsoseparation weak 1: Dorsoseparation sharp Webbing colour contrast 0: Absence of webbing colour contrast 1: Presence of webbing colour contrast Survival rates Sexual maturity Mating systems Life history traits Details about the period of activity. 0: No diurnal species. 1: Diurnal species. 0: No nocturnal species. 1: Nocturnal species. 0: Species diurnal or nocturnal. 1: Species diurnal and nocturnal. Survival rates in males Survival rates in males. Survival rates in females Survival rates in females. Adult survival rates Survival rates in adults, when no sex specific data were available. Sexual maturity in years. Sexual maturity in males Sexual maturity in males, in years. Sexual maturity in females Sexual maturity in females, in years. Adult sexual maturity Sexual maturity in adults, when no sex specific data were available, in years. Structuration of sexual behaviour relationships during the breeding season. We recorded 2 different types of mating systems through amphibians: polygyny when a male has mating relationships with several females; polyandry when a female has mating relationships with several males. 0: No polyandry species. 1: Polyandry species 0: No polygyny species. 1: Polygyny species. Details about clutch size, egg laying mode, eggs and young characteristics. When the species is viviparous, number of offspring by female by clutch. When the species is ovoviviparous, number of eggs by female by clutch. When the species is ovoviviparous, number of offspring by female by clutch. Clutch position Eggs can be lay at different places in the breeding environment. On surface on nonpermanent lentic ponds Breeding season Explosive or prolonged Parental care Presence of parental care Transport of eggs Transport of tadpoles Guarding eggs Defend eggs Water eggs Food active or passive Food of juveniles 0: Eggs are not laid on surface on non-permanent lentic ponds. 1: Eggs are laid on surface on non-permanent lentic ponds. 0: Prolonged breeding season. 1: Explosive breeding season. Parental care is defined as any behaviour of parents for increasing the fitness of their young. Most of amphibians do not perform parental care, but a few transport, guard and defend their eggs. 0: Absence of parental care. 1: Presence of parental care. 0: Parents do not transport their eggs. 1: Parents transport their eggs. 0: Parents do not transport their tadpoles. 1: Parents transport their tadpoles. 0: Parents do not guard their eggs. 1: Parents guard their eggs. 0: Parents do not defend their eggs. 1: Parents defend their eggs. 0: Parents do not humidify their eggs. 1: Parents humidify their eggs. Food passive (sit-and-wait) Food active (active foragers) 0: Juveniles are not carnivorous. 1: Juveniles are carnivorous. 0: Juveniles are not insectivorous. 1: Juveniles are insectivorous. 0: Juveniles are not moluscivorous. 1: Juveniles are moluscivorous. Food of adults Metabolism rates Death simulation Unken reflex Communication Mode of communication 0: Species do not use visual communication. 1: Species uses visual communication. 0: Species do not use acoustic communication. 1: Species uses acoustic communication. 0: Species do not use chemical communication. 1: Species uses chemical communication. 0: Juveniles are not herbivorous. 1: Juveniles are herbivorous. 0: Juveniles are not detritivorous. 1: Juveniles are detritivorous. 0: Adults are not carnivorous. 1: Juveniles are carnivorous. 0: Juveniles are not insectivorous. 1: Juveniles are insectivorous. 0: Juveniles are not moluscivorous. 1: Juveniles are moluscivorous. 0: Juveniles are not cannibals. 1: Juveniles are cannibals. 0: Juveniles are not herbivorous. 1: Juveniles are herbivorous. 0: Juveniles are not detritivorous. 1: Juveniles are detritivorous. Metabolism rate in adults. Mode of defense 0: Species do not use secretion as mode of defense. 1: Species uses secretion as mode of defense. 0: Species do not use toxicity as mode of defense. 1: Species uses toxicity as mode of defense. 0: Species do not use death simulation as mode of defense. 1: Species uses death simulation as mode of defense. 0: Species do not use unken reflex as mode of defense. 1: Species uses unken reflex as mode of defense. 0: Species do not use other mode of defense. 1: Species uses other mode of defense. Male territorial Female territorial Both territorial 0: Species do not use seismic communication. 1: Species uses seismic communication. Territoriality can serve individuals to defend their nest, den, sexual partners, mating sites or high quality resources sites needed for themselves or their young. We recorded species for which individuals develop a territorial behaviour (by scent markings or fighting) during the breeding season. 0: Both males and females not territorial. 1: Both males and females territorial. Home range Home range Movement event Movement event 0: Movement events performed by one single individual (solitary individual). 1: Movement events performed by several individuals (social individuals). Dispersal active or passive Dispersal active or passive Sex-biased dispersal Sex-biased dispersal Mode of displacement Dispersal stage juvenile Dispersal stage adult Dispersal stage during breeding season Mean dispersal distance Mean dispersal distance, in meters. Maximum dispersal distance Maximum dispersal distance, in meters. Minimal dispersal distance Minimal dispersal distance, in meters. 0: Passive dispersal. 1: Active dispersal. Dispersal abilities can be significantly different between genders. We reported here if sex-biased dispersal was identified in species (if males have faster or longer dispersal abilities than females). 0: No sex-biased dispersal reported in the literature. 1: Significant sex-biased dispersal reported in the literature. 0: Individuals do not walk during displacement event. 1: Individuals walk during displacement event. 0: Individuals do not jump during displacement event. 1: Individuals jump during displacement event. 0: Individuals do not run during displacement event. 1: Individuals run during displacement event. 0: Individuals do not climb during displacement event. 1: Individuals climb during displacement event. 0: Individuals do not swim during displacement event. 1: Individuals swim during displacement event. 0: Individuals do not crawl during displacement event. 1: Individuals crawl during displacement event. Contrary to migration, dispersal is defined as individual movement could induce gene flow. Dispersal distances came from mark-release-recapture and/or radiotracking studies. 0: Dispersal event not at juvenile stage. 1: Dispersal event at juvenile stage. 0: Dispersal event not at adult stage. 1: Dispersal event at adult stage. 0: Dispersal event not during breeding season. 1: Dispersal event during breeding season. Contrary to dispersal, migration is defined as individual movement that not induces gene flow. Migration distances came from mark-release-recapture and/or radiotracking studies. Migration stage adult Migration stage during breeding season 0: Migration event not at adult stage. 1: Migration event at adult stage. 0: Migration event not during breeding season. 1: Migration event during breeding season. Mean migration distance Mean migration distance, in meters. Maximum migration distance Maximum migration distance, in meters. Minimal migration distance Minimal migration distance, in meters. Spatial distribution of the species in South America, calculated with GIS tools, in km². 0: The spatial distribution of the species is not punctual. 1: The spatial distribution of the species is punctual. 0: Less than 25% of the spatial distribution of the species is not in South America. 1: Less than 25% of the spatial distribution of the species is in South America. 0: Between 25 and 50% of the spatial distribution of the species are not in South America. 1: Between 25 and 50% of the spatial distribution of the species are in South America. 0: Between 50 and 75% of the spatial distribution of the species are not in South America. 1: Between 50 and 75% of the spatial distribution of the species are in South America. 0: Up to 75% of the spatial distribution of the species is not in South America. 1: Up to 75% of the spatial distribution of the species is in South America. Distribution of the species in Australia. Spatial distribution of the species in Australia, calculated with GIS tools, in km². Global Distribution IUCN status Data Deficient Least Concern Near Threatened Critically Endangered Population trend 0: Less than 50% of the spatial distribution of the species is not in Australia. 1: Less than 50% of the spatial distribution of the species is in Australia. 0: Up to 50% of the spatial distribution of the species is not in Australia. 1: Up to 50% of the spatial distribution of the species is in Australia. 0: The species is not ubiquist. 1: The species is ubiquist. 0: The species is not subendemic. 1: The species is subendemic. 0: The species is not endemic. 1: The species is endemic. IUCN threat status. Threatened species have one of the three following IUCN status: “vulnerable”, “endangered”, “critically endangered”. 0: Data sufficient for the species. 1: Data deficient for the species. 0: IUCN status for the species is not Least Concern. 1: IUCN status for the species is Least Concern. 0: IUCN status for the species is not Near Threatened. 1: IUCN status for the species is Near Threatened. 0: IUCN status for the species is not Vulnerable. 1: IUCN status for the species is Vulnerable. 0: IUCN status for the species is not Endangered. 1: IUCN status for the species is Endangered. 0: IUCN status for the species is not Critically Endangered. 1: IUCN status for the species is Critically Endangered. Evolution of the population. Population trends vary between “decrease”, “stable” and “increase”. Data Deficient Major Threats Habitat loss Invasive alien Climate change Natural disasters Change dynamics Intrinsic factors Human disturbance 0: Data sufficient for the species. 1: Data deficient for the species. 0: Population trend for the species is not Decrease. 1: Population trend for the species is Decrease. 0: Population trend for the species is not Stable. 1: Population trend for the species is Stable. 0: Population trend for the species is not Increase. 1: Population trend for the species is Increase. Major threats impacting the species. 0: Habitat loss does not affect the species. 1: Habitat loss affects the species. 0: Invasive alien does not affect the species. 1: Invasive alien affects the species. 0: Harvesting does not affect the species. 1: Harvesting affects the species. 0: Accidental does not affect the species. 1: Accidental affects the species. 0: Persecution does not affect the species. 1: Persecution affects the species. 0: Pollution does not affect the species. 1: Pollution affects the species. 0: Climate change does not affect the species. 1: Climate change affects the species. 0: Natural disasters do not affect the species. 1: Natural disasters affect the species. 0: Change dynamics do not affect the species. 1: Change dynamics affect the species. 0: Intrinsic factors do not affect the species. 1: Intrinsic factors affect the species. 0: Human disturbance does not affect the species. 1: Human disturbance affects the species. 0: Factors affecting the species are known. 1: Factors affecting the species are unknown. DOI: 10.1111/j.1461- 0248 . 2009 .01434.x Authors: Trochet A, Moulherat S , Calvez O , Schmeller DS , Clobert J , Stevens VM Data type: life history traits Brief description: Summary of morphometric and life-history traits for 86 European amphibian species. Values expected for the life-histories have been averaged between studies (i.e. between populations) . NA means that data were not available in the literature .
